title: Broadneck's Ali'i Niumatalolo settles on Boise
text:
Broadneck's Ali'i Niumatalolo settles on Boise First day of football practice at Broadneck By Joshua McKerrow / Baltimore Sun Media Group Broadneck's Ali'i Niumatalolo practices with his team on the first day of football practice. Broadneck's Ali'i Niumatalolo practices with his team on the first day of football practice. (By Joshua McKerrow / Baltimore Sun Media Group) Bob Hough Contact Reporter bhough@capgaznews.com 
It was one of the most-asked questions heading into the high school football season. 
"Who's he going to sign with?" was a common question when discussing Broadneck senior linebacker Ali'i Niumatalolo. The son of Navy coach Ken Niumatalolo took a step toward making his college selection official when he announced via Twitter on Tuesday he has verbally committed to Boise State of the Mountain West Conference. 
"After a ton of prayer and fasting and talking to my family, I've officially committed to Boise State," said Niumatalolo, via his Twitter account, @Aliiniumatalolo, shortly before 10 p.m. Tuesday. 
Niumatalolo had drawn interest from several other Division I programs, but ultimately decided on the Broncos late Tuesday night. Boise State made their official offer in June. He was also interested in Brigham Young, Utah and Connecticut. 
"I wanted to commit to them ever since I got the offer, but I wanted to make sure it was the right fit," Niumatalolo said. "I really like it there." 
Niumatalolo was a first-team All County selection a year ago with 108 tackles, including 12½ for losses, four sacks and two interceptions. Through seven games this year, he already has 17½ tackles for losses, four sacks, two interceptions and a caused fumble. He's also been involved on offense, catching five passes for 118 yards (23.6 yards/catch) and scoring a pair of touchdowns. Broadneck defeats Glen Burnie By Paul W. Gillespie / Capital Gazette Broadneck's Ali'i Niumatalolo plays tight end in first quarter. The Broadneck Bruins defeated the visiting Glen Burnie Gophers, 41-20, in high school football Saturday afternoon. Broadneck's Ali'i Niumatalolo plays tight end in first quarter. The Broadneck Bruins defeated the visiting Glen Burnie Gophers, 41-20, in high school football Saturday afternoon. (By Paul W. Gillespie / Capital Gazette) 
"Ali'i is the best defensive player I have coached," Broadneck coach Rob Harris said. "He is a young man that is only beginning to scratch the surface of his talent and that is scary. Boise State in my opinion is getting a big-time steal." 
Niumatalolo's brother, Va'a, graduated from Broadneck in 2011 and is a junior at Brigham Young University, which has gone independent in football but does play Boise State annually. 
As a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, Niumatalolo will serve a two-year mission before reporting to Boise State. Boise State has requested he go on his mission right away following graduation so he'll be ready to fill a need when he reports for the 2018 season.
